steps.text: Study materials for certification obtained from Arkansas State Plant Board.
Obtain study materials from University of Arkansas Cooperative Extension Service, pesticide labels, and manufacturers.
Ensure intended use of pesticides is consistent with product label.
Maintain daily pest management programs.
Address pests from facility and surrounding areas.
Follow federal and state regulations.
Implement proper engineering design.
Maintain short grass and trimmed shrubs.
Install paved access and proper drainage.
Create an 18- to 24-inch gravel strip around foundation.
Place night-lights at least 30 feet away from doors.
Keep framing at least four inches from walls.
Fill necessary voids with materials like polyurethane foam.
Install concrete or coated concrete floors.
Use acid-proof or brick floors for wet processing areas.
Seal and clean wall materials.
Use few windows with good transparency.
Install metal and tight-fitting doors.
Install air curtains at large doors.
Use dust-tight lighting fixtures.
Install electrical and plumbing services for easy access.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass. Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns. Ensure proper drainage. Position lighting away from buildings.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps. Maintain housekeeping and implement pest monitoring programs.
(Rodents) Maintain bait stations. (Insects) Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites. (Birds) Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate.
Rodent-proof all openings. Screen windows. Eliminate cracks, crevices, and ledges. Block bird access to ledges.
Keep all areas free of loose materials. Clean structures and equipment frequently.
Use electrified grids inside for insect attraction.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Store materials away from walls for inspection access.
Use rodent traps near doors.
Use air curtains at doors.
Implement a detailed monitoring program and a total facility IPM program.
Form an inspection committee.
Compile a list of deficiencies.
Thoroughly inspect all areas.
Record and distribute notes.
Departments correct defects.
Committee reviews and assign dates.
Inspect suspect areas using a flashlight.
Spread out stock on a flat surface for observation.
Inspect areas most likely to produce results.
Observe employee actions and in-plant practices.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm.
Require a written inspection procedure for incoming raw products.
Maintain housekeeping standards and pallet-cleaning program.
Inspect stored product regularly.
Use visual inspection as a key method.
Minimize insect movement by inspecting incoming materials.
Use pheromone-baited traps for inspecting bagged commodities.
Determine the extent of a problem based on trap catches.
Use pheromone traps for monitoring and interception.
Place traps on facility perimeter.
Adapt trap placement to temperature gradients.
Inspect traps regularly for pest presence.
Read label information printed on pesticide container.
Apply pesticides only in accordance with label instructions.
Identify food areas, nonfood areas, and food processing facilities.
Apply pesticides as general residual in nonfood areas.
Apply spot treatments to limited areas in food areas.
Apply crack and crevice treatments in food areas.
Identify life cycles of beetles and moths.
Understand four stages: egg, larva, pupa, adult.
Recognize larvae features: chewing mouthparts, feed on food.
Determine moth larvae have legs on back half.
Identify beetle larvae lack legs on back half.
Inspect food products for moths and beetles.

Identify specific pests: Almond Moth, Indianmeal Moth, Mediterranean Flour Moth, Mealmoth, Lesser Grain Borer, Cigarette Beetle, Drugstore Beetle, Confused Flour Beetle, Sawtoothed Grain Beetle, Merchant Grain Beetle, or Foreign Grain Beetle.
Implement control measures based on pest identification: avoidance, sanitation, heat treatment, cold treatment, residual insecticides, space sprays, or fumigation.

constraints.text: Use pesticides safely and follow label directions.
Preventive design and maintenance are crucial in managing pests.
Require an 18-inch space between pallets and walls for inspection.
A written inspection procedure is required by law for raw product receiving.
Use pheromone-baited traps for identifying pests.
Place one trap per 4,000-5,000 square feet in high-risk areas.
Monitor trap catches for increases in numbers.
Use pitfall traps or deflecting dust traps in dusty areas.
Follow federal and state regulations for pesticide applications.
Ensure pesticides have tolerances or exemptions for food products.
Ensure use of USDA-approved pesticides in meat plants.
Avoid using residuals in production areas.
Check for signs of moths and beetles such as webbing, silken threads, or adult presence.
Ensure proper storage conditions to prevent infestations: keep food dry and cool.
